block.p: Verizon's Unions Agree To Draw Up Unified Plan With a midnight deadline looming in which representatives for nearly two-thirds of 86,000 striking workers planned to end formal talks with Verizon Communications, negotiators sought to resolve issues including job security and mandatory overtime.
The unions' three main bargaining units, which were divided on Wednesday, agreed to draw up a unified proposal last night, a person close to the talks said. [Page C5.]

UAL Lowers Earnings Estimates UAL, parent of United Airlines, lowered its third-quarter earnings estimates, citing the thousands of canceled flights that have come amid a dispute with its pilots. The airline also announced several initiatives to placate its disgruntled passengers, including frequent-flier bonuses and elimination of certain service fees. [C7.]

For Firestone, a Jubilee That Wasn't This was supposed to be a jubilee year for Firestone. One hundred years ago, on Aug. 3, 1900, to be exact, Harvey S. Firestone established the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, and Firestone was planning to celebrate that fact, in a big way. Then it all came crashing down. Firestone tires have been implicated in 62 deaths and countless injuries. Now Firestone's ad campaign is revolving around notices in 41 newspapers, detailing the mechanics of a huge tire recall. Advertising. [C2.]

Stock Options Take Center Stage The retirement package awarded to Dick Cheney, the Republican nominee for vice president, is neither the largest nor the most generous ever given a chief executive officer. But the estimated $20 million package from Halliburton is remarkable in other ways. It has brought executive compensation back from the dead as a campaign issue and has elevated stock option wealth -- and the potential conflicts it may pose to politicians who have amassed it -- to center stage. [A23.]

Chip Makers Lead Shares Higher Stocks rose, led by semiconductor makers, as investors bet that technology shares would weather a slowing economy. The Nasdaq composite index ended up 79.67 points, or 2.06 percent, to 3,940.87, while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 47.25 points, or 0.43 percent, to 11,055.64. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.22 points, or 1.10 percent, to 1,496.07. [C6.]

Toysmart Database Plan Set Aside A federal bankruptcy judge set aside a Federal Trade Commission plan limiting the ability of the retailer Toysmart.com to sell its customer database as part of its liquidation. [C2.]

Wireless Auction Nets $50 Billion The most expensive auction in history ended today, when six companies bid nearly $50 billion for licenses to offer a new generation of wireless communications in Germany, the largest economy in Europe. ''For consumers, the result promises the most intense competition,'' said Klaus-Dieter Scheurle, head of Germany's telecommunications regulatory agency and the auction's architect. ''This was the most favorable solution.'' [C4.]
Molecule Used in Electronic Circuit Chemists at the University of California at Los Angeles are reporting a further advance in the effort to produce electronic circuitry on a molecular scale. [C5.]

Mexico Rejects Sugar Trade Plan A protracted dispute over sugar trade between Mexico and the United States escalated when the Mexicans rejected a U.S. proposal and requested a special arbitration hearing under a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement. [C4.]
